title: Lesson 14: Stem Cells and Differentiation
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding stem cell potency, cellular differentiation through gene expression, and applications in medical research.
learningIntentions: Students can distinguish between totipotent, pluripotent, and multipotent stem cells in terms of differentiation potential.
Students can explain the process of cellular differentiation (specialisation) as differential gene expression.
Students can discuss the significance of stem cells in medical research and therapy (ethical and therapeutic considerations).

syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can define potency and place stem cell types on a hierarchy.
I can explain why differentiated cells have the same DNA but different structures/functions.
I can give one example of a current stem cell therapy and one ethical consideration.

engagementHook.title: The Master Cells
engagementHook.content: 'You started as a single cell that could become anything—heart, brain, bone, blood. As you developed, those cells made decisions, narrowing their options until they became specialised. But some cells keep their options open—these are stem cells. Today we explore the hierarchy from 'can become anything' to 'can become one thing,' and why doctors see them as the future of medicine.'

keyConcepts.definition: Unspecialised cells that can divide (self-renew) and differentiate into specialised cell types.

Totipotent: Can form all cell types including placental cells (e.g., zygote). Pluripotent: Can form all embryonic cell types but not placenta (e.g., embryonic stem cells). Multipotent: Can form multiple cell types within a specific lineage (e.g., haematopoietic stem cells).
Process where cells become specialised in structure and function. Involves differential gene expression (different genes switched on/off), not loss of DNA. All cells retain complete genome.

Bone marrow transplants (multipotent), skin grafts for burns, potential for treating spinal cord injuries, diabetes, Parkinson's. Ethics: Source of embryonic stem cells (destruction of blastocyst) vs adult stem cells.

misconceptions.correction: All somatic cells have identical DNA (except gametes/immune cells). Differentiation is about which genes are expressed, not which genes are present.

misconceptions.misconception: Adult stem cells can become any cell type
misconceptions.correction: Adult stem cells are typically multipotent (limited lineage), not pluripotent.

misconceptions.misconception: Stem cells are only found in embryos
misconceptions.correction: Adult stem cells exist (bone marrow, fat, skin, brain), though less versatile than embryonic.

contentSections.title: The Potency Pyramid
contentSections.content: Triangle showing Zygote (Totipotent) at top → Embryonic Stem Cells (Pluripotent) → Adult Stem Cells (Multipotent) → Differentiated cells at base (e.g., neuron, muscle, blood). Arrows showing narrowing potential.
contentSections.example: Bone marrow transplant—multipotent blood stem cells regenerate immune system.

image.caption: The potency pyramid: from totipotent to differentiated cells

contentSections.title: Differentiation – Same DNA, Different Destiny
contentSections.content: All cells contain same genome (library), but different books (genes) are open. Liver cells express albumin gene; nerve cells express neurotransmitter genes. Epigenetics concept (simplified): chemical tags that switch genes on/off without changing DNA sequence.
contentSections.example: Identical twins (same DNA) but different fingerprints, different gene expression patterns over life.

activities.title: Ethical and Therapeutic Trade-offs
activities.description: Evaluate the options for a patient needing new heart cells.
activities.content:
Scenario: A patient needs new heart cells.

Option A: Embryonic stem cells (pluripotent, grow well, but embryo destroyed)
Option B: Adult stem cells from patient (no rejection, but hard to grow, limited types)

Consider:
- Therapeutic benefits of each
- Ethical concerns
- iPSCs (induced pluripotent) as future solution

multipleChoice.question: Which type of stem cell can differentiate into any cell type of the body but cannot form placental cells?
multipleChoice.rationale: Pluripotent definition. Can form all three germ layers but not extraembryonic tissues (placenta).

multipleChoice.question: Cellular differentiation involves:
options: Loss of DNA from the nucleus
multipleChoice.rationale: Gene expression concept. Same DNA, different genes active in different cell types.

multipleChoice.question: A major ethical concern regarding embryonic stem cell research is that it:
options: Uses cells from adult bone marrow
multipleChoice.rationale: Core ethical issue. Obtaining embryonic stem cells typically requires destroying the blastocyst.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between multipotent and pluripotent stem cells. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Pluripotent stem cells can differentiate into any of the three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm)/all body cell types (but not placental)
1 mark: Multipotent stem cells can differentiate into a limited range of cell types within a specific lineage (e.g., blood cells only, or nerve cells only)
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating multipotent can form 'many' without specifying limited lineage.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why differentiated cells such as skin cells and nerve cells have different structures and functions despite containing the same DNA. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Differentiation involves differential gene expression (different genes are switched on or off)
1 mark: Skin cells express genes for keratin; nerve cells express genes for neurotransmitters (specific examples of different proteins)
1 mark: All cells retain the complete genome / DNA sequence is identical but gene expression patterns differ (or epigenetic modification mentioned)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying they have different DNA; saying genes are 'lost' during differentiation.

definitions: Stem cells are unspecialised cells that can divide and differentiate.
Totipotent: Can form all cells + placenta (zygote).
Pluripotent: Can form all body cell types but not placenta (embryonic stem cells).
Multipotent: Can form specific cell types only (adult stem cells, e.g., bone marrow).
Differentiation = differential gene expression (same DNA, different genes active).
keyPoints: Differentiation = gene expression changes, not DNA loss
Adult = multipotent, already in therapy use
diagrams: Gene expression in different cell types

shortAnswer: Pluripotent stem cells can differentiate into cell types from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), meaning they can potentially form any cell type in the body, but they cannot form placental or extraembryonic tissues. Multipotent stem cells are more limited; they can differentiate into multiple cell types but only within a specific lineage or family. For example, haematopoietic stem cells in bone marrow can form various blood cells (red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets) but cannot form nerve cells or muscle cells.

Differentiated cells such as skin cells and nerve cells contain the same DNA because they originated from the same zygote through mitosis. However, they have different structures and functions because of differential gene expression. During differentiation, specific genes are switched on or off through epigenetic mechanisms. For example, skin cells express genes for producing keratin (structural protein), while nerve cells express genes for producing neurotransmitters and ion channels. This selective gene expression produces different proteins, leading to different cell structures and specialised functions, even though all cells retain the complete genome.
